Author: mynameishere
Content: I'm still inclined to give the position to steam. Coaxing a lump of coal to do more work than a team of horses was an exponential shift (while staying within the realm of widespread application, unlike fission.)

Author: pg
Content:
The first was probably the use of language or tools. (Hard to say which came first, since other animals use tools too after a fashion.) After that the control of fire, the domestication of animals, agriculture, the city...

Fortunately they seem to occur at increasingly small intervals.

Author: pg
Content: Here too apparently. Currently 6/30 stories on the front page have the word "Facebook" in them.

Author: Goladus
Content: http://www.paulgraham.com/hs.html - What You'll Wish You'd Known

Author: Goladus
Content: I agree. Google connects people to information.  Facebook connects people to people.  Information, once created, doesn't change.  People do.

Author: twism
Content: how you store them, to how they are fetched, to how they are displayed and arranged according to popularity (i think thats how news.yc works) on every vote.

Author: Goladus
Content:
I don't mean to measure FB by Google criteria, that was mainly a response to what seemed to be a rather vacuous question from the article. Maybe I misunderstood, but people asking "why Google, why now?" in 2002 probably didn't use the internet at all or had a vested interest in some other search engine.

I can believe social networking technology will be huge, but I think enough human relationship aspects are mutually exclusive that it will be far more difficult for one service to completely dominate. "Why Facebook, why now?" is a much more interesting question than "Why Google, why now?"
